body:
[Conditional compilation](http://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/language_basics.html#conditional-compilation) is a feature that was inherited from Pyrex that never had a high standing amongst the Cython developers. It also takes up quite a bit of code space in the syntax nodes and the parser.

See the discussion in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4287

I would like to deprecate it in Cython 3.0.
It could be one of the things that we remove for Cython 3.1.

comment_data.body:
I'd be in favour in principle.

It might be worth trying to work out how much real code it'll break. I'm not completely sure the best way to do that right now - possibly by scraping [the PyPI dependent packages](https://libraries.io/pypi/Cython/dependents)?

A quick check of scipy turned up [this use](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/44e31b1eb202ef91caad059952ba268d2610a60b/scipy/stats/biasedurn.pyx.templ#L10) so at least one project would need some adapting.

```
DEF NPY_OLD = {NPY_OLD}
...
IF not NPY_OLD:
```

Although this is a niche feature, it can be used.
But I agree that the likelihood is high that there will be more pythonic ways to achieve the same result.
Both DEF and IF are quite useful for imports, since it doesn't make much sense to check for something at interpretation time that can be checked at compile time.

In short, DEF and IF benefit from whatever is determined at compile time.

While not many people think about it, what about UB/IB handling?
For example `INT_MIN / -1` for c++
in the case when `INT_MIN! = -INT_MAX` we must define the behavior of `INT_MIN / -1` ourselves, so as not to accidentally get stuck in an infinite loop, or so that our calculations do not suddenly return an incorrect result.
It is very convenient to wrap it in IF:

```cython
int safe_int_div(int a, int b):
    if b == 0:
        return 1

    IF INT_MIN != -INT_MAX:
        if a == INT_MIN and b == -1:
            return 1

    return a / b
```

Also numpy project is using them:

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/623bc1fae1d47df24e7f1e29321d0c0ba2771ce0/numpy/random/_philox.pyx#L14
pyimgui uses [DEF](https://github.com/pyimgui/pyimgui/blob/480b4de8ab82adaa2cd310100330b41f40274bcc/imgui/core.pyx#L37)
Some scipy tutorial uses [DEF](https://github.com/kwmsmith/scipy-2017-cython-tutorial/blob/3e72e31fc27dc1f44582926f4a01a4c29ee79abb/cython_mcmc/cython_mcmc/mcmc.pyx#L10-L11)

As I understand the discussion, `DEF` is OK, it is the `IF` that is more troubling (the "conditional" in "conditional compliation". Also: too many examples is going to make this discussion unwieldy. Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it. I apologize for starting it off.

> too many examples is going to make this discussion unwieldy. Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it.

of course, just a couple of examples, no more needed here
PyBoy uses [IF](https://github.com/Baekalfen/PyBoy/blob/b39a988e263d9830701d35d426fcd143d25e9ac9/pyboy/core/lcd.pxd#L30)

> ```cython
>     IF INT_MIN != -INT_MAX:
> ```

This is decidedly _NOT_ a use case for conditional compilation. It should be handled at C compile time.

> It should be handled at C compile time.

exactly, and as I understand it, cython cannot convert this expression to `#ifdef` and pass it to the compiler?

To clarify, what takes up code space is the separate calculation of constant values in the parser (i.e. `DEF`). The conditional statements (' IF'  etc.) are trivial compared to that. They are just a wart in the language.

I would personally like to see `IF` removed, at some point. I could live with keeping a way to define constants, although I don't think they'd have to be handled by the compiler. We already do constant folding (although we do not inject all constant values in the end, e.g. floats to prevent loss/gain of precision). I could imagine something like a `cython.once()` which would make sure that an expression is only evaluated once (and then cached, or, if compile time constant, injected as a constant at compile time). OTOH, I'm not sure it's worth breaking existing code for that.

The [use case in SciPy](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/44e31b1eb202ef91caad059952ba268d2610a60b/scipy/stats/biasedurn.pyx.templ#L77) is an exemplary one, if I understand it correctly. It seems to be using template code generation to inject a constant flag, but then uses `IF` to switch between different code sections. Why not use the templating language for that?

I'm sure users are still writing such code as we're discussing this, and IMHO they shouldn't. I've added a warning to the documentation and would also like to add a visible compile time deprecation warning. Would that be ok for everyone?

Then we can discuss the removal again in a couple of years from now, maybe with a better standing.

> Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it

here are some examples #4314
@scoder to fully understand when the behavior of `IF` will differ from `if`?  Or like what's the difference?

> @scoder to fully understand when the behavior of `IF` will differ from `if`? Or like what's the difference?

To be more specific, what legit `IF` expression will not have the same result as if we replace `IF` with `if`?

> add a visible compile time deprecation warning

That sounds like a good plan, and would encourage people to not use it.

I would be in favor of deprecating as well. 

Some `IF` expressions that would not be legal if replaced by if are those that use, for example, nonexistent or differently typed function calls in the different branches. (Either templating or a C-level shim can be used instead.)

It seems that most uses of `DEF` could be replaced by a global variable as well, though it's possible that would hurt the ability to optimize away some things at the C level even for a sophisticated compiler (for full expressions, literal constants should be fine). In a few cases (array sizes) we require a constant. Perhaps we could be smart enough here with an "ordinary" global.

Please be mindful of use cases like https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4291, which CuPy relies on a lot. Sorry I don't have time to open a discussion in the mailing list yet, but it doesn't mean I don't care...

cc: @kmaehashi

Yeah this is pretty useful when detecting the version of a dependency before adding certain code (like forward declarations or handling other differences between library versions). Have used `IF` to handle differences between Python versions specifically.

> As I understand the discussion, `DEF` is OK, it is the `IF` that is more troubling (the "conditional" in "conditional compliation"

Well, @mattip idk, but it looks like [`DEF` is not OK](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4286#issuecomment-887222354), at least @scoder doesn't really want to leave this in cython as I understand it

milestone.description: Remove support for Python 2 and Python < 3.5. Maybe also for Python 3.5, TBD.

title: Deprecate conditional compilation
